subsection.text: Subject to valid existing rights, there is established the Sanhedrin Special Conservation Management Area (referred to in this section as the conservation management area), comprising approximately 12,254 acres of Federal land administered by the Forest Service in Mendocino County, California, as generally depicted on the map entitled Sanhedrin Conservation Management Area and dated May 15, 2020.
The purposes of the conservation management area are—

paragraph.text: to conserve, protect, and enhance for the benefit and enjoyment of present and future generations the ecological, scenic, wildlife, recreational, roadless, cultural, historical, natural, educational, and scientific resources of the conservation management area;
to protect and restore late-successional forest structure, oak woodlands and grasslands, aquatic habitat, and anadromous fisheries within the conservation management area;
to protect and restore the undeveloped character of the conservation management area; and
to allow visitors to enjoy the scenic, natural, cultural, and wildlife values of the conservation management area.
The Secretary shall manage the conservation management area—

subparagraph.text: in a manner consistent with the purposes described in subsection (b); and
in accordance with—

clause.text: the laws (including regulations) generally applicable to the National Forest System;
this section; and
any other applicable law (including regulations).

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall only allow uses of the conservation management area that the Secretary determines would further the purposes described in subsection (b).

Except as provided in paragraph (3), the use of motorized vehicles in the conservation management area shall be permitted only on existing roads, trails, and areas designated for use by such vehicles as of the date of enactment of this Act.
Except as provided in paragraph (3), no new or temporary roads shall be constructed within the conservation management area.
Nothing in paragraph (1) or (2) prevents the Secretary from—

subparagraph.text: rerouting or closing an existing road or trail to protect natural resources from degradation, or to protect public safety, as determined to be appropriate by the Secretary;
designating routes of travel on land acquired by the Secretary and incorporated into the conservation management area if the designations are—

clause.text: consistent with the purposes described in subsection (b); and
completed, to the maximum extent practicable, not later than 3 years after the date of acquisition;

subparagraph.text: constructing a temporary road on which motorized vehicles are permitted as part of a vegetation management project carried out in accordance with paragraph (4);
authorizing the use of motorized vehicles for administrative purposes; or
responding to an emergency.
In this paragraph, the term decommission means, with respect to a road—

clause.text: to reestablish vegetation on the road; and
to restore any natural drainage, watershed function, or other ecological processes that are disrupted or adversely impacted by the road by removing or hydrologically disconnecting the road prism.

subparagraph.text: Not later than 3 years after the date on which the applicable vegetation management project is completed, the Secretary shall decommission any temporary road constructed under paragraph (3)(C).

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2), no harvesting of timber shall be allowed within the conservation management area.
The Secretary may authorize harvesting of timber in the conservation management area—

subparagraph.text: if the Secretary determines that the harvesting is necessary to further the purposes of the conservation management area;
in a manner consistent with the purposes described in subsection (b); and
subject to—

clause.text: such reasonable regulations, policies, and practices as the Secretary determines to be appropriate; and
all applicable laws (including regulations).

subsection.text: The grazing of livestock in the conservation management area, where established before the date of enactment of this Act, shall be permitted to continue—

paragraph.text: subject to—

subparagraph.text: such reasonable regulations, policies, and practices as the Secretary considers necessary; and
applicable law (including regulations); and

paragraph.text: in a manner consistent with the purposes described in subsection (b).

subsection.text: Consistent with this section, the Secretary may carry out any activities within the conservation management area that the Secretary determines to be necessary to control fire, insects, or diseases, including the coordination of those activities with a State or local agency.

subsection.header: Acquisition and incorporation of land and interests in land

paragraph.text: In accordance with applicable laws (including regulations), the Secretary may acquire any land or interest in land within or adjacent to the boundaries of the conservation management area by purchase from a willing seller, donation, or exchange.
Any land or interest in land acquired by the Secretary under paragraph (1) shall be—

subparagraph.text: incorporated into, and administered as part of, the conservation management area; and
withdrawn in accordance with subsection (i).

subsection.text: Subject to valid existing rights, all Federal land located in the conservation management area is withdrawn from—

paragraph.text: all forms of entry, appropriation, and disposal under the public land laws;
location, entry, and patenting under the mining laws; and
operation of the mineral leasing, mineral materials, and geothermal leasing laws.

subsection.text: Congress finds that, for purposes of section 603 of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1782), any portion of the Eden Valley Wilderness Study Area that is not designated as a wilderness area or wilderness addition by section 301(a) has been adequately studied for wilderness designation.

Any portion of a wilderness study area described in subsection (a) that is not designated as a wilderness area or wilderness addition by section 301(a) is no longer subject to section 603(c) of the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 (43 U.S.C. 1782(c)).
As soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall prepare maps and legal descriptions of—

paragraph.text: the South Fork Trinity-Mad River Restoration Area established by section 101(b);
the Horse Mountain Special Management Area established by section 201(a);
the wilderness areas and wilderness additions designated by section 301(a);
the potential wilderness areas designated by section 303(a); and
the Sanhedrin Special Conservation Management Area established by section 305(a).

subsection.header: Submission of maps and legal descriptions
subsection.text: The Secretary shall file the maps and legal descriptions prepared under subsection (a) with—

paragraph.text: the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources of the Senate; and
the Committee on Natural Resources of the House of Representatives.

subsection.text: The maps and legal descriptions prepared under subsection (a) shall have the same force and effect as if included in this Act, except that the Secretary may correct any clerical and typographical errors in the maps and legal descriptions.

The maps and legal descriptions prepared under subsection (a) shall be on file and available for public inspection in the appropriate offices of the Forest Service, the Bureau of Land Management, or the National Park Service, as applicable.

section.header: Updates to land and resource management plans
section.text: As soon as practicable after the date of enactment of this Act, in accordance with applicable law (including regulations), the Secretary shall incorporate the designations and studies required by this Act into updated management plans for units covered by this Act.

section.header: Pacific Gas and Electric Company utility facilities and rights-of-way

subsection.text: Nothing in this Act—

paragraph.text: affects any validly issued right-of-way for the customary operation, maintenance, upgrade, repair, relocation within an existing right-of-way, replacement, or other authorized activity (including the use of any mechanized vehicle, helicopter, and other aerial device) in a right-of-way acquired by or issued, granted, or permitted to Pacific Gas and Electric Company (including any predecessor or successor in interest or assign) that is located on land included in—

subparagraph.text: the South Fork Trinity-Mad River Restoration Area established by section 101(b);
the Horse Mountain Special Management Area established by section 201(a);
the Bigfoot National Recreation Trail established under section 202(b)(1);
the Sanhedrin Special Conservation Management Area established by section 305(a); or

paragraph.text: prohibits the upgrading or replacement of any—

subparagraph.text: utility facilities of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, including those utility facilities in existence on the date of enactment of this Act within—

clause.text: the South Fork Trinity-Mad River Restoration Area known as—

subclause.text: Gas Transmission Line 177A or rights-of-way;
Gas Transmission Line DFM 1312-02 or rights-of-way;
Electric Transmission Line Bridgeville-Cottonwood 115 kV or rights-of-way;
Electric Transmission Line Humboldt-Trinity 60 kV or rights-of-way;
Electric Transmission Line Humboldt-Trinity 115 kV or rights-of-way;
Electric Transmission Line Maple Creek-Hoopa 60 kV or rights-of-way;
Electric Distribution Line-Willow Creek 1101 12 kV or rights-of-way;
Electric Distribution Line-Willow Creek 1103 12 kV or rights-of-way;
Electric Distribution Line-Low Gap 1101 12 kV or rights-of-way;
Electric Distribution Line-Fort Seward 1121 12 kV or rights-of-way;
Forest Glen Border District Regulator Station or rights-of-way;
Durret District Gas Regulator Station or rights-of-way;
Gas Distribution Line 4269C or rights-of-way;
Gas Distribution Line 43991 or rights-of-way;
Gas Distribution Line 4993D or rights-of-way;
Sportsmans Club District Gas Regulator Station or rights-of-way;
Highway 36 and Zenia District Gas Regulator Station or rights-of-way;
Dinsmore Lodge 2nd Stage Gas Regulator Station or rights-of-way;
Electric Distribution Line-Wildwood 1101 12kV or rights-of-way;
Low Gap Substation;
Hyampom Switching Station; or
Wildwood Substation;

clause.text: the Bigfoot National Recreation Trail known as—

subclause.text: Gas Transmission Line 177A or rights-of-way;
Electric Transmission Line Humboldt-Trinity 115 kV or rights-of-way;
Electric Transmission Line Bridgeville-Cottonwood 115 kV or rights-of-way; or
Electric Transmission Line Humboldt-Trinity 60 kV or rights-of-way;

clause.text: the Sanhedrin Special Conservation Management Area known as Electric Distribution Line-Willits 1103 12 kV or rights-of-way; or
the Horse Mountain Special Management Area known as Electric Distribution Line Willow Creek 1101 12 kV or rights-of-way; or

subparagraph.text: utility facilities of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company in rights-of-way issued, granted, or permitted by the Secretary adjacent to a utility facility referred to in subparagraph (A).

subsection.text: Not later than the later of the date that is 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act or the date of issuance of a new utility facility right-of-way within the South Fork Trinity-Mad River Restoration Area, Bigfoot National Recreation Trail, Sanhedrin Special Conservation Management Area, or Horse Mountain Special Management Area, the Secretary, in consultation with the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, shall publish plans for regular and emergency access by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company to the inholdings and rights-of-way of the Pacific Gas and Electric Company.
